data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Title
data.value: AdLer Input Support

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Title
data.value: Quality Check

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Info.Text
data.value: In the context of competency-based higher education and the associated shift in perspective "from teaching to learning" and "input to output", as well as the increasing focus on student-centered learning, learning outcomes have gained significant attention.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Button.Create
data.value: Create

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.NotSpecified
data.value: Not specified

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel
data.value: Taxonomy Level

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Info
data.value: The formulation of a learning outcome focuses on the description of corresponding competencies of the intended learning process of the students. These can be assigned to a taxonomy level based on the complexity of the cognitive processes. The definition of a taxonomy level (according to Anderson & Krathwohl) serves to find a suitable action verb in the further processing steps of the learning outcome formulation.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Intro
data.value: The students will be able to...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility
data.value: Action verb*

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.Info
data.value: The learning outcome describes which competencies the students will have developed at the end of the learning process. It therefore describes actions that are formulated with the help of verbs of visibility. These represent an action on or with an external object. Verbs such as "understand" or "recognize" are therefore not suitable. The verbs of visibility can be assigned to a taxonomy level.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.Placeholder
data.value: Formulate or select

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.RequiredError
data.value: Specification of the verb is necessary

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.RequiredError
data.value: Specification of "What" is necessary

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What
data.value: What? (Topic)*

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.Info
data.value: The "What" specifies the learning content (subject matter) that is addressed as part of the students' competency development. Combined with an action verb and the corresponding taxonomy level, it describes a competency that students should have developed by the end of the learning process.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Text
data.value: by...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby
data.value: Whereby?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Info
data.value: The "Whereby" describes the theoretical or practical tools that students use to carry out their actions. These might include formulas, models, plans, concepts, tools, etc., that are taught during the course and practiced through application. The use and integration of these tools provide the foundation for competent actions.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Text
data.value: to...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Info
data.value: The "What for" provides insight into the purpose and intention behind the learning unit. It emphasizes the practical applications that students will have once they have mastered the material. The "What for" illustrates the actions or opportunities students will be able to engage in, often in more complex environments and under more challenging conditions than those found in the learning situation. The “What for” does not refer to the examination.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor
data.value: What for?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Text
data.value: 1. First, think about the taxonomy level at which you want to formulate your learning outcome.

data.value: Preview of the formulated learning outcome:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Understand

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Apply

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Analyse

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Evaluate

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Copy
data.value: Copy to clipboard

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part1
data.value: Constructive Alignment, as described by Biggs (2011), is a didactic principle that has particular application in higher education pedagogy. It aims to align teaching/learning activities and assessments with the objectives of teaching/learning units. In this approach, educators design their courses in a way that creates a coherent link between learning outcomes, teaching/learning activities, and assessments.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Text.Image
data.value: The illustration shows the connection between these three components, along with guiding questions educators should consider during course design.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part3
data.value: This approach creates a cognitive process in which the dimensions of learning outcomes, assessments, and learning activities are aligned and interconnected. The stronger this alignment, the greater the potential of the course to promote learning and enhance students' competencies.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Title
data.value: What is Constructive Alignment?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Title
data.value: What are learning outcomes?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part1
data.value: In literature, terms such as "learning objectives" or "learning output" are often used as alternatives to "learning outcomes." However, these terms are frequently used interchangeably, leading to a maze of terminological ambiguities. For this reason, the term "learning outcomes" is consistently used throughout the AdLer input support system.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Title
data.value: Why is the use of learning outcomes important in teaching?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part1
data.value: Educators benefit from using constructive alignment. By precisely formulating learning outcomes, they gain clarity about their intentions, which guide their actions in planning, delivering, and evaluating their teaching. Without clear formulation, many learning outcomes remain unspoken and are therefore difficult to reflect upon. As a result, they cannot—or can only partially—be used as tools for designing effective instruction. Additionally, the use of learning outcomes lays the foundation for student-centered teaching, as it prompts educators to consciously consider the alignment of their teaching with the learning outcomes and reflect on their formulation.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part2
data.value: Students can better understand the goals of a course through the use of learning outcomes. Learning outcomes can be used as a communication tool to avoid misunderstandings between educators and students, as they bring greater transparency and clarity to a course or a lesson unit. This enhances learning success.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.One
data.value: Are the students the real protagonists in the plot?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Two
data.value: Is the process of the activity understandable to an outsider?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Three
data.value: Do the verbs describe an action performed on/with an external learning object?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Four
data.value: Can the statement be turned into a clear assessment task?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Five
data.value: Is the workload of the learning process appropriate?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Six
data.value: Are the theoretical or practical tools for the task identified?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Subtitle
data.value: Reflection questions to check high-quality formulated learning outcomes:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Seven
data.value: Is the purpose of the learning unit clearly communicated?

data.value: Website for the AdLer project

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelOne
data.value: Input support for formulating learning outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelTwo
data.value: What are learning outcomes?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelThree
data.value: What is a Learning Outcome Taxonomy?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelFour
data.value: How are learning outcomes formulated?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Sources
data.value: References

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: Type of Outcomes and Level of Instruction

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.DescriptionText.Image
data.value: Figure: Constructive Alignment

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part2
data.value: For educators, this means that they first formulate learning outcomes during the course planning process and use these as a foundation. Next, they design the corresponding assessments to evaluate the achievement of the desired competencies. In the third step, they select learning activities that optimally support students on their path to reaching the learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part2
data.value: Learning outcomes describe what students should know and be able to do, as well as the attitudes they are expected to demonstrate by the end of a learning segment or process. Learning outcomes are, therefore, the most precise description possible of the intended learning results. They are documented in writing and communicated in a context-appropriate manner.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part3
data.value: Additionally, learning outcomes can be distinguished based on their level of specificity and the duration of the instructional unit (e.g., an entire module or a single lesson). As the duration of the instructional unit decreases, the specificity of the outcomes increases. Conversely, the broader the instructional unit, the more abstract the learning outcomes become. A distinction can be made between general, intermediate, and specific outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part1.Italic
data.value: Educators

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part2.Italic
data.value: Students

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part3
data.value: Learning outcomes usually have an indirect positive effect: while effective learning time directly contributes to success, clearly formulated learning outcomes lead students to use more class time effectively as learning time. Additionally, clear learning outcomes enable students to engage more purposefully with the course content.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part4
data.value: For student-centered teaching, it is also crucial that students accept the defined learning outcomes and actively engage with them. Well-formulated learning outcomes, through increased transparency, can positively influence student engagement. They provide a meaningful starting point for students to effectively and independently manage their learning process.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Table.Col.One
data.value: Type of Outcome

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Title
data.value: What is a Learning Outcome Taxonomy?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Info.Text.PartOne
data.value: Learning outcomes can be assigned to different competency levels, and the classification schema of learning outcome taxonomies can be used for this purpose. This serves as a methodological tool for formulating learning outcomes and helps educators describe them in a competency-oriented way.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Info.Text.PartTwo
data.value: One of the most well-known taxonomies is Bloom's Taxonomy of Educational Objectives (1984), which includes six cognitive process dimensions (also known as learning outcome levels). Anderson & Krathwohl (2001) further developed Bloom's Taxonomy. This revision serves as the foundation for the AdLer input support system and will be explained in more detail below.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Title
data.value: The Taxonomy for Learning, Teaching and Assessing According to Anderson & Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part3
data.value: The various taxonomy levels are not in a strictly defined hierarchical relationship, though dependencies can occur. For example, a person cannot evaluate which of two analysis methods is better suited for a specific process ("Evaluate") without first understanding both methods ("Understand"). On the other hand, it is entirely possible for someone to apply a method ("Apply") without fully understanding it ("Understand").

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part2
data.value: The following table provides an overview of the different levels of Anderson & Krathwohl’s learning outcome taxonomy, supplemented by a brief description and sample "action verbs" that indicate the corresponding cognitive process. These action verbs should be used when formulating learning outcomes for the respective competencies at each taxonomy level. Depending on the context, a verb may be applicable across multiple levels of the taxonomy.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part1
data.value: The six taxonomy levels categorize the different cognitive processes that can come into play during learning. This classification describes varying levels of complexity of the targeted competencies. It represents a spectrum ranging from simple learning goals, such as recalling facts, to complex processes like creating new ideas. Anderson & Krathwohl's taxonomy includes the following six levels: Remembering, Understanding, Applying, Analyzing, Evaluating, and Creating. Each of these levels represents a specific type of cognitive process. The structure of the taxonomy allows educators to assign learning outcomes to a particular level of complexity and incorporate this into the formulation of their goals.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One
data.value: Taxonomy Level

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Description

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Examples for Action Verbs

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.One
data.value: Remember

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Two
data.value: Understand

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Three
data.value: Apply

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Four
data.value: Analyze

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Five
data.value: Evaluate

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Six
data.value: Create

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: Remembering is the ability to bring information to mind or recall it without necessarily understanding it. This involves accessing relevant knowledge stored in long-term memory.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: Understanding is the ability to comprehend and interpret information (in oral, written, or graphic form).

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: Applying can be defined as the ability to execute or use a learned procedure (a schema or method) in a specific situation.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Four
data.value: Analyzing can be defined as the ability to break down learning content into its constituent elements and determine how these elements are related or connected to form an overarching structure or serve an overarching purpose.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Five
data.value: Evaluating is the ability to assess the significance, quality, or value of something based on criteria or standards.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Six
data.value: Creating is the ability to assemble elements into a coherent or functioning whole or to reorganize elements into a new pattern or structure.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: list, name, define, recite

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: describe, represent, explain, summarize

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: calculate, handle/process, operate, execute

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: select, test, compare, examine/investigate

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: justify, decide, evaluate, classify

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Six
data.value: design, develop, construct, assemble

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: The Taxonomy for Learning, Teaching and Assessing According to Anderson & Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.RightSidebar.One
data.value: What is a Learning Outcome Taxonomy?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.RightSidebar.Two
data.value: Learning outcome taxonomy according to Anderson & Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.RightSidebar.One
data.value: What are learning outcomes?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Title
data.value: How are learning outcomes formulated?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Info.Text
data.value: Learning outcomes describe what students should know and be able to do, as well as the attitudes they are expected to demonstrate by the end of a learning segment or process. Learning outcomes are thus the most precise description of the intended learning results.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part1
data.value: For learning outcomes to have their intended positive impact on learning, they must be formulated according to certain principles and communicated clearly to students.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2
data.value: The core elements of learning outcomes consist of both a content and a process component:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2.List1
data.value: The content component describes the subject-specific or cross-disciplinary knowledge that the students' learning process is focused on.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2.List2
data.value: The process component specifies an observable action that students should perform. This is important because the achievement of a learning outcome can only be recognized through the students' actions.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspects
data.value: Reis (2013) identifies five key aspects that should be considered when formulating learning outcomes:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.One.Title
data.value: Student Perspective:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Two.Title
data.value: Specify Concrete Actions:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Three.Title
data.value: Use of Action Verbs:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Four.Title
data.value: Measurable standards:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Five.Title
data.value: Realistic expectations:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.One
data.value: Learning outcomes must be written as student-centered activities. It is not enough for students to merely be the grammatical subject of the sentence. Phrases like "The students get to know..." or "The students experience..." represent hidden teaching interventions because the focus of the activity is on the instructor, not the student. Instead, the outcome should reflect what students actively do, such as "Students analyze...", "Students solve...", etc.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Two
data.value: Learning outcomes should be as concrete as possible. The steps or actions required should be clear and understandable from an external perspective. A well-defined action structure helps students better grasp the expectations, allowing them to align their learning process accordingly.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Three
data.value: To link teaching interventions with student actions, "action verbs" must be used in the formulation of learning outcomes. These verbs describe what students are expected to "do" with the learning content. Verbs like "understand" or "recognize" are inadequate because they don't clearly convey the action or performance. For instance, phrases like "Students understand the basics of..." are not helpful, as they raise the question: What action is intended here? Additionally, only one verb should be used per learning outcome for clarity.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Four
data.value: A learning outcome should describe an action in such a way that it can be evaluated using clear criteria. If the declarative statement is rephrased as an imperative, it should form a clear assessment task, describing what needs to be done, whereby, and for what purpose. This ensures that the required action can actually be performed by the students. For example, in an exam, it is only possible to verify if students have understood something if they actively demonstrate it—such as by recalling a definition, applying a formula, or analyzing a case study. This aspect is crucial to ensure that students can indeed carry out the required task.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Five
data.value: Each learning outcome corresponds to a learning process that requires time for the necessary actions. Overly ambitious or numerous outcomes within a limited time frame lead to an increase in instructional elements, which can result in compensating student activities with teacher interventions. This diminishes students' active engagement in the learning process.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Title
data.value: The "what-whereby-what-for" structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part1
data.value: In general, the formulation of a learning outcome can follow a systematic sentence structure: subject, an action verb, and learning content (and context).

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Text.Image
data.value: The following example illustrates this:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.DescriptionText.Image
data.value: Figure: (1) subject, (2) action verb, (3) learning content (and context)

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part3
data.value: When applying this structure to the aforementioned example of a learning outcome, the following expanded version emerges:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part2
data.value: The quality of a learning outcome can be further improved by using the "What-Whereby-What-For" structure. The following table describes this structure:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: What-whereby-what-for structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One
data.value: Component

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Description

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Guiding Questions

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.One
data.value: What?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.Two
data.value: Whereby?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.Three
data.value: What for?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: The "What" specifies the learning content (subject matter) that is addressed as part of the students' competency development. Combined with an action verb and the corresponding taxonomy level, it describes a competency that students should have developed by the end of the learning process. The "What" aligns with the systematic sentence structure of a learning outcome.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: The "Whereby" describes the theoretical or practical tools that students use to carry out their actions. These might include formulas, models, plans, concepts, tools, etc., that are taught during the course and practiced through application. The use and integration of these tools provide the foundation for competent actions.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: The "What for" provides insight into the purpose and intention behind the learning unit. It emphasizes the practical applications that students will have once they have mastered the material. The "What for" illustrates the actions or opportunities students will be able to engage in, often in more complex environments and under more challenging conditions than those found in the learning situation. The “What for” does not refer to the examination.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: What exactly can students do at the end of the course?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: With what do students achieve the competency?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: What "tools" do students use to apply the competencies they are developing?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: For what (specific and/or long-term) purpose should the competencies be acquired?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: Why do students need the competencies gained after the course?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.What
data.value: The students will be able to identify the different genera of the bird of prey species "eagle" on the basis of its plumage,

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.Whereby
data.value: ... by accurately classifying the coloring of individual feathers with the aid of specialist literature

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.WhatFor
data.value: ... to correctly categorize eagles living in the wild during a bird excursion.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.One
data.value: How are learning outcomes formulated?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.Two
data.value: What-whereby-what-for structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualitycheckForLearningOutcomes.Title
data.value: Quality Check for Formulating Learning Outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualitycheckForLearningOutcomes.Text
data.value: The following quality check for well-formulated learning outcomes serves as a practical guide. Answering the reflection questions is useful for critically analyzing the final formulation of the learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.Three
data.value: Quality Check for learning outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: Quality Check for Learning Outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.One
data.value: No.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Category

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Reflection Question

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: Learning outcomes formulated as student activity

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: Concrete activity

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: Action verbs

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Four
data.value: Measurable standards

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Five
data.value: Realistic expectations

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Six
data.value: Theoretical / practical tools

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Seven
data.value: Purpose and application

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: Are the students the real protagonists in the plot?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: Is the process of the activity understandable to an outsider?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: Do the verbs describe an action performed on/with an external learning object?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: Can the statement be turned into a clear assessment task?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: Is the workload of the learning process appropriate?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Six
data.value: Are the theoretical or practical tools for the task identified?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Seven
data.value: Is the purpose of the learning unit clearly communicated?

data.value: 2. Now formulate a learning outcome.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Definition.LearningOutcomes.Title

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelOne.LandingPage
data.value: - Welcome -

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelOne.LandingPage.Title
data.value: Welcome to the input support for formulating learning outcomes!

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelOne.LandingPage.TextOne
data.value: This tool helps you to formulate learning outcomes effectively. In the left-hand navigation column, you can access various information on the topic and also use the input support.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelOne.LandingPage.TextTwo
data.value: Take a look at the content and then formulate a learning outcome.
